item.title: Internet Wholesale Bandwidth Options
item.description: Two main types of organizations buy internet bandwidth: end users and resellers. End users, such as businesses, need access for their employees. Resellers, also known as Internet Service Providers (ISPs), purchase large amounts of bandwidth and divide it among numerous individuals and businesses, aiming to profit from the difference between wholesale and retail prices. The biggest networks, called Tier 1, are integral to the internet’s core and don’t purchase access. Instead, they exchange traffic equally with other Tier 1 networks through a process called peering, which benefits all without financial transactions.

item.title: Dedicated Bandwidth vs Cable
item.description: Businesses choose dedicated internet services, like T1 lines and Ethernet over Copper, when they prioritize consistent performance and service guarantees, or when shared options aren’t available. Cable broadband, on the other hand, attracts businesses with its high bandwidth for a lower cost. Although cable lacks service guarantees, its proven track record and widespread availability, especially during business hours, make it appealing. The term “dedicated” in this context signifies that a specific bandwidth amount is exclusively allocated to the user.

item.title: Why T1 Is Available Where Other Line Services Arenâ€™t
item.description: Businesses located outside of city centers may struggle to obtain the same quality of network services as their downtown counterparts. While it may seem like options are limited, a reliable and affordable digital telecom service called T1 is often accessible in these areas. Contrary to outdated beliefs, T1 lines are no longer prohibitively expensive or geographically restricted. They are widely available for businesses, though they may not be suitable for residential use.

item.title: 3 Mbps to 6 Mbps Bonded Internet Access
3 Types of Clouds You Should Know About
item.description: The increasing popularity of cloud-based IT services might leave you wondering if you’re missing out. To help you decide, let’s explore the three primary cloud types and which applications are well-suited for cloud environments. These days, it seems everyone is offering cloud services, primarily based on three architectures: public, private, and hybrid clouds. The most common is the public cloud, a specialized data center owned and operated by a provider serving numerous paying customers concurrently.

item.title: Many Flavors of Business Internet
item.description: By: John Shepler Connecting your business to the internet is crucial in today’s world. It’s practically impossible to operate without a broadband connection. Customers, cloud services, backups, suppliers, and even connections to home offices or remote locations rely on it. The question is, how can you establish the best connection for your business? Businesses have numerous options for internet service, but the variety can be overwhelming. Choosing the cheapest option might leave you frustrated if it can’t handle your needs.

item.title: Hosted Network Monitoring Services
item.description: The increasing reliance on electronic transactions, online services, and cloud technologies has made networks essential for businesses. This dependence requires IT departments to prioritize network monitoring, either through in-house solutions or external providers. While companies have traditionally monitored their internal networks, extending this practice to telecom connections is crucial. This includes dedicated lines, public internet connections, and VPNs. Let’s explore ways to enhance network monitoring processes. Smaller businesses often face challenges with network monitoring outside of business hours.

item.title: Dedicated vs Shared Internet Access
item.description: There are two main types of broadband internet: shared and dedicated. While you might be familiar with terms like wireless, landline, satellite, or fiber optic, these refer to delivery methods that impact price and availability. Your primary choice lies in deciding between shared and dedicated internet access. What sets them apart? The names are quite descriptive. Shared internet access resembles a buffet where you might eye a large roast, hoping for a full plate.
